content:
Diagnosis:	Prostate adenocarcinoma T2b N0 M0, diagnosed March 2024

I reviewed [redacted name] today in the prostate cancer clinic. He is currently on cycle 3 of docetaxel chemotherapy as part of his treatment plan. His initial PSA was 6.9 at diagnosis, and latest PSA has shown good response dropping to 2.1. Molecular testing revealed CHEK1 mutation.

He is tolerating the chemotherapy reasonably well with grade 1 fatigue and mild peripheral neuropathy affecting his fingertips. No significant nausea or other toxicities. Performance status remains 0. Blood results today show stable FBC and biochemistry with neutrophils 2.8 and normal LFTs.

On examination, he remains well with no concerning features. Digital rectal examination shows reduced prominence of the original lesion at the prostatic base.

He will continue with planned docetaxel, with next cycle due in 3 weeks. We will see him again prior to cycle 4 with repeat PSA measurement.

cancer_timeline.value: PSA dropped to 2.1 showing good response

patient_facts.value: Grade 1 fatigue and mild peripheral neuropathy affecting fingertips
Digital rectal examination shows reduced prominence of lesion at prostatic base
Stable FBC and biochemistry with neutrophils 2.8 and normal LFTs

status_updates.value: Localized prostate cancer showing good biochemical response to docetaxel chemotherapy with manageable toxicity
Good PSA response dropping from 6.9 to 2.1
Grade 1 fatigue and mild peripheral neuropathy
Review prior to cycle 4 with repeat PSA
